comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Well to start,  it is before 1974,  because that was when the long pier connecting the ferry wharf to the acquarium was destroyed in a storm,   if memory serves me correctly.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
There is hardly a car to be seen.   But there are lots of people on the beach,  so it wasn't taken at 5 AM or some funny time.   I can't see any trams or buses anywhere either.    Kalajzich's hotel is not built.  There are a few cars parked on the side of the road, but none moving anywhere,  which seems a bit odd.   I can't see any of the 1960's-70's era style units.   The Harbord Diggers is just out of shot.  Can't see any tram tracks.  The absence of cars seems so strange,  I am wondering if it is some unusual time,  like 11 AM on Armistice Day,   or during the running of the Melbourne Cup or maybe Christmas Day.
Some expert will know about the various configurations of the wharves at Manly.
The height of the trees on the ocean-side waterfront might also be a clue.   I know there was a big die-off due to detergent in the sewage  in the late 70's but the photo is well before that.
I will guess 1939.

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content: Manly Oceanworld is not there, so definitely before 1962. There are cars parked on the harbour side of the Esplanade behind the beach but I can't make out enough detail to suggest a year.

comment.author: 64403351@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] 
It's some time between 1933 and 1939. The promenade walkway opened in 1933 and the old clock tower was destroyed by fire in 1939. The ferry would be the SS Dee Why or SS Curl Curl.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/davidbromage] Thanks for all your comments and detective work here - 1933-1939 is a good date range to have determined.
AB

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: They started demolishing the eastern half of this wharf in 1938 for the new one.
